<</SYS>>[INST] ###Question: Is it possible to lose eyesight and it mean nothing? 22F, 5Ûª6Û,207lbs, caucausian. One time event. Vape and smoke weed. I work in electrical so considered the possibility of damage from dust. History of bulimia which is currently active (would say 3-4 days are purge days). It comes down to last night, on a walk, I got excessively dizzy and weak. I kept on walking with vision in both eyes intermittently disappearing (never both eyes at once) eventually when the weakness peaked (it felt hard to identify words at this point, was on phone call) my left eye lost all vision for about 30 seconds. Afterwards the extreme blur stayed for about two hours. Had a big olÛª headache behind the left eye about an hour after vision loss. Still do, pulsing, changing in intensity at random. ###Answer: Neurosurgeon here.We use an unnecessarily fancy term for that: amaurosis fugax which means transient vision loss. It results from the retina not getting enough blood flow for a short period of time (the ophthalmic artery is the first to branch from the internal carotid artery and also has collateral flow from the external carotid in some people) and can be considered a stroke symptom, making it a TIA (transient ischemic attack: basically pre-stroke). Though since you're young, I wouldn't put a stenotic ICA or CCA on the top of my list as the "sudden, short and quickly recovered loss of vision" is more commonly a result of your blood pressure being too low for a short period of time. In other words your heart couldn't keep up to your brains oxygen (blood flow) needs for a short while but eventually adjusted, just a little bit late. If the symptom repeats, I would (if I were to see you as a patient in clinic or maybe the ER) refer you to a cardiologist and maybe also consider a brain vessel imaging (a CTA or MRA, whichever is preferred). Considering your history, dehydration may have exacerbated the issue so try to stay hydrated. A syncope event itself is mostly okay as blood flow to the brain is usually immediately recovered but falling down and hitting your head on something like concrete may not.

###Answer: The ultrasound that is performed around 11-13 weeks of pregnancy is very important in order to detect certain abnormalities that can be seen early in pregnancy. The one image you have provided does not help a lot. However, absent nasal septum can be a worrying sign, although not always indicative of an actual problem with the fetus since it can be seen later in pregnancy. I have seen mothers with small noses have fetuses that looked like that on ultrasound but were born completely normal. Regarding the brain abnormalities, some cannot be seen clearly so early in pregnancy and some can be corrected later on. If absence of cerebellum is confirmed however, it can turn out to be a very serious condition for the newborn and can lead to severe developmental delay and neurological problems later in life. You should for sure have another ultrasound by a specialist in that field. You might need also further testing, e.g. amniocentesis to confirm. I don't want to sound extremely alarming but you should also think about the possibility of terminating such a pregnancy if severe abnormalities are confirmed. ###Answer: Atelectasis isnÛªt an uncommon finding. It just means your lung in that area is not being inflated. It is indeed collapsed. This can be for any number of reason but for most it is due to lack of exercise or activity. ItÛªs also common in those with recurrent infections or get bronchitis because gunk builds up and blocks airways from getting proper aeration. Typically when you work your body, you tend to breath in harder which opens up all portions of your lungs. Your lungs are made up of tons of tiny little balloons (alveoli). The balloons at the bottom of your lung sometimes need extra force to really open them up. In your case, if you have scarring in that area, it may be even harder to inflate. Atelectasis is when the balloons collapse and havenÛªt been opened up in some time. It looks like your lung tissue has shrunken but typically isnÛªt a problem unless a large portion of your lung is affected. If youÛªve never tried one, a spirometer might be beneficial to help open up this portion of your lung. Guaifenesin to clear out mucus may also help.
